title: Why were spices so important in the ancient world? - Quora

response.answer_text: Spices were a rarity, depending on where you lived, and the level of rarity controlled the price; some of which came from thousands of miles away. They were essential for cooking and in some cases, for medicine (the most valuable “spice” if you will was, of course salt, which was often used as a preservative as well as for flavoring and even in medicines, which was worth its weight in gold. Workers were sometimes even paid in salt instead of silver or gold). Spices were also used in making perfumes and incense (heavily used not just by the churches, by the nobles to help cover the smell of open sewers like moats, and “water closets” (or restrooms). and the castle in general. Thus, it was their scarcity and numerous uses that made spices to valuable.

No refrigeration! Most food was boiled, salted, pickled, or dried to preserve it. And usually not without some consequences as hygienic standards weren't aware of bacteria then.The taste of food preserved by such methods wasn't exactly a culinary highlight either, so spices added both flavor and hid some rather unpleasant smells & tastes when food was overcooked, overripe, or perhaps semi-rotten. Underdeveloped countries in tropical zones use many hot spices for exactly the same reason today.Spices were portable and often used as both currency and medium of exchange in antiquity making their usage even more prevalent and widespread.But let's be clear that for most of that era’s population; spices were rarities as commodities and used solely among the upper classes. The average laborer ate pottage.
